rotor 0.1.0.9000
  • Reference

    rotor

    rotor is aimed to provide a cross platform R reimagination of logrotate as a companion package to https://github.com/s-fleck/lgr. In addition to rotating log files, it can also be used as a (very primtivie) backup tool.

    rotate(), rotate_date(), and rotate_time() move a file and insert a suffix (either an integer or a timestamp) into the filename. In addition, they create an empty file in place of the original one. This is useful for log rotation.

    backup(), backup_date() and backup_time() do the same but keep the original file.

    Installation

    And the development version from GitHub with:

    # install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("s-fleck/rotor")

    Example

    The examples below all use backup() because it’s a bit more convenient to write examples for than rotate(), but the later works mostly the same.

    library(rotor)

    First we must create a temporary directory and an example log file.

    # setup test file for examples
dr <- tempdir()
td <- file.path(dr, "rotor")
dir.create(td, recursive = TRUE)
tf <- file.path(td, "test.log")
saveRDS(cars, tf)

    backup() makes a copy of a file and inserts an index between the filename and the file extension. The file with the index 1 is always the most recently made backup.

    backup(tf)
backup(tf)
backup(tf, compression = TRUE)  # backup and rotate also support compression

list_backups(tf)  # returns all backups of a file
#> [1] "/tmp/RtmpPCJbB0/rotor/test.1.log.zip"
#> [2] "/tmp/RtmpPCJbB0/rotor/test.2.log"    
#> [3] "/tmp/RtmpPCJbB0/rotor/test.3.log"

    You can also set a maximum number of backups to be kept

    backup(tf, max_backups = 4)
backup(tf, max_backups = 4)
backup(tf, max_backups = 4)

list_backups(tf)
#> [1] "/tmp/RtmpPCJbB0/rotor/test.1.log"    
#> [2] "/tmp/RtmpPCJbB0/rotor/test.2.log"    
#> [3] "/tmp/RtmpPCJbB0/rotor/test.3.log"    
#> [4] "/tmp/RtmpPCJbB0/rotor/test.4.log.zip"

    prune_backups() deletes all backups of a file except for max_backups. If we set max_backups to 0, we can clean up all backups.

    prune_backups(tf, max_backups = 0)

    Instead of backup up with an index, you can also add a timestamp.

    backup_date(tf)
backup_time(tf)
list_backups(tf)
#> [1] "/tmp/RtmpPCJbB0/rotor/test.2019-04-28--18-42-09.log"
#> [2] "/tmp/RtmpPCJbB0/rotor/test.2019-04-28.log"
    prune_backups(tf, max_backups = 0)  # cleanup
list_backups(tf)
#> character(0)
